utterances: Okay.
It's very concerning.

And I really wish that the international community could step up on some level and protect these people ,because, like I said, I mean, they proved to the whole world, they were there for a peaceful protest.
They were there for seven days without any incident.
They were self-policing themselves to make sure that whoever was showing up to demonstrations did not have any weapons.
And then this onslaught by the pro-Mubarak demonstrators has just, you know, everything has taken a completely different turn, and it's a very worrisome, you know, turn, obviously.
The security of people is now at risk and, badly, they've managed to very, very, very intentionally scare people.
This is a scare tactic that's being carried out, and it's succeeding because the government is in charge of food supplies.
The government is in charge of gasoline supplies.
And now the government is, you know, making the people feel unsafe.
All the banks are closed.
People have no access to money.
People have no access to food.
And they're getting worried.
And they're getting scared.
And they're trying to figure out, is this the price I want to pay for democracy?
Is this -you know?
And, unfortunately, people are just being terrorized...
Okay.
...for lack of a better word.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Okay.
Baheera, thanks so much for your call.
And we hope that your loved ones in Egypt stay safe through all this.
Thank you.
I hope so too.
Thank you for hearing me.
Bye-bye.
Sameh Abdelaziz, you were in Atlanta as we mentioned.
I know you are in contact with a lot of Egyptian Americans who are there.
I understand you've launched a Facebook page and helped to organize an anti-Mubarak rally down there in Atlanta.
How is that effort going?
Let me make a small correction.
It is not anti-Mubarak...
Okay.
...demonstration.
It is a pro-democracy, pro-freedom, pro -these people that put their life on the line.
What Baheera said is absolutely correct.
This is not a new invention.
He's working from the same workbook or copybook that he used over and over again - over the last 30 years.
We are here not to talk with Mubarak or even try to reason with Mubarak.
That's we're beyond this long time ago.
We're here to talk to our American government.
What's happening now, we have at least partial responsibility for.
And this is why we organized this rally last Saturday.
We're going out to Atlanta again this Saturday in front of CNN building.
Like you said, we had a lot of interviews and a lot of media.
And the message is one: We cannot count on the -on Mubarak to be civilized.
He showed that he's completely out of this league.
It's our government that have a lot of relationships invested heavily in Egypt over the 30 years.
And it is our government that should make it very clear where it stands.
It is not equal sides.
And we're trying to balance our position.
Our position should be very clear.
We're talking with Sameh Abdelaziz, who's in Atlanta.
He's Egyptian American, and is in touch with other Egyptian Americans watching events very closely in Cairo and elsewhere in Egypt.
You're listening to TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
Let's get another caller here.
We have Michael on the line from Fresno, California.
Hi, Michael.
Go ahead.
Hello?
How are you?
How are you doing?
I'm great.
Thanks.
Tell us your story.
Yes.
I've been watching (unintelligible) news for a couple of weeks now.

And then my friends are all telling me from the Tahrir Square, that the ministry of defense released the prisoners - ordered the release the prisoners from the public prisons and to - and paid them off, telling them to be pro-Mubarak.
And they're the ones who actually got the horses and all the camels from the tourist sections, and they ran on the Tahrir Square against people.
These are all prisoners and thugs paid off by the Mubarak government.
And...
Michael, it sounds - hmm.
It sounds like you're talking with friends or relatives back in Egypt.
How are you able to stay in touch?
How are you tracking the events that are unfolding there?
I'm chatting either on Facebook and Twitter sometimes.
Mm-hmm.
But mainly on Facebook, because everyone is uploading videos over there - and YouTube as well.
They are many videos on how the so-called pro-Mubarak are fighting against the anti-government.
And these are not anti-government.
These are anti-corruption people who are peaceful demonstrations in Tahrir Square.
And, you know, and they're being forced upon the pro-Mubarak demonstrators, like I don't understand why are you pro-Mubarak and not just go home.
Why are you coming and fighting against the other one, you know?
Hmm.
All right...

And my cousin actually was on the - in a - one of the demonstrations, and he said that people are holding knives and pipes and running all the streets, seeing if someone is anti-government, and they would take him and fight him and stuff.
Oh, sorry.
Well, we hope that your cousin and others that you're in touch with stay safe there.
Thank you, ma'am.
Appreciate it.
Thank you for the call, Michael.
Thank you.
Thanks.
Thank you.

Sameh Abdelaziz, I'm curious, as you watch the images and speak to people there, is there one image, you know, a specific moment that stands out in your mind as a turning point in these protests so far, kind of a sign of the times that you'll look back and point to as you remember these events?
So are we talking about a up moment or down moment?
Well, I don't know.
I suppose it depends...
(Soundbite of laughter)
...where it will all go tomorrow and over the weekend.
I really would like to think that, 10 years from now, I will remember how these kids - I left Egypt when I was 29 years old.
Now I'm 51.
I still go back every year because my parents are still there.
They are over 75 -my sisters, my extended family.
And I can tell you, Mary Louise, every time I went there, within two weeks, I felt so bad.
I felt that I need to go back home because, although I think of myself as Egyptian American, the country I was visiting wasn't Egypt that I knew.
That's the bad part.

I think my proudest moment was seeing these kids on the 25th and 26th, standing, singing national anthem and songs about Egypt, about history, about beautiful old songs that I haven't heard for years.
I want to keep this image.
I hope that there is some mechanism somewhere that I will delete completely the images of yesterday, of people attacking people from the top of camels.
I don't know if somebody thought that it came out of a postcard or something.

This has nothing to do with Egypt, Egypt that - the people that were trying to protect journalists yesterday, the people that were cleaning El Tahrir Square, these are the Egyptians and these are the images I want to keep for the rest of my life.
All right.
We'll leave it there with those words of hope from Sameh Abdelaziz.
Thanks so much for taking the time to come on the program today.
Thank you so much, Mary Louise.
That's Sameh Abdelaziz.
He is a senior IT manager at a banking firm in Atlanta.
He's obviously tracking events and keeping in touch with his family in Egypt, closely.
Congresswoman, thank you so much for talking with us.
Thank you, Michel.

I'm Mary Louise Kelly.
This is DAY TO DAY.
I'm Alex Cohen.
And I'm Madeleine Brand.
This weekend in Blacksburg, Virginia, graduation ceremonies are being held at Virginia Tech University.
It's been nearly a month since a student gunman killed 32 people on the campus.
At a ceremony tonight the university will award the students who were killed posthumous degrees.
Their families will be presented with class rings.
And more than 4,000 students will gather at Lane Stadium for a commencement speech by retired General John Abizaid.
One of the students who will be there is Michelle Billman.
Michelle is a graduating senior and general manager of WUVT - that's the student radio station.
I spoke with Michelle about her final days as a student at Virginia Tech.
